setup.question: According to Retief what would happen if the Corps did not get involved in the dispute between the Boyars and the Aga Kagans?
answers: The Aga Kagans would enslave the Boyars
The Boyars and the Aga Kagans would go to war

Text.text:
I think both of these things are true within the context of the story.
Proof of slavery in reference to Aga Kagans:
. Note that the first instance directly shows Retief (the head negotiator for the diplomatic Corps) making reference to the AK's slaving practice, which follows from their established practice of

Because of the tension between the Boyars and Aga Kagans, Retief says that he needs to bring concrete evidence of Corps assistance to the situation, otherwise they will have a shooting war. The evidence is pretty conclusive here, and we have no textual evidence which can cause us to doubt Retief's words throughout the story.

A: You show that the Aga Kagans are slavers, but can you speak to Corps intervention with them and the Boyars
b: Do you have any more specific evidence? "shooting" is far from a war.
Absolutely! Here are some direct quotes: Retief speaking:

This last one is spoken by the Boyar delegate, not Retief, but it's part of the same ongoing convo about Corps involvement.

And to address B's perspective: I actually think it's not unreasonable to assume that war might happen, but it's not really the _point_ of why the Corps intervene.
The question is asking "According to Retief," that's a pretty key idea in this debate. Directly according to retief,

. Even if shooting is far from war, according to Retief, there will be a "war" without Corps involvement, the evidence is really direct.

Also when it comes to B's ev, it is never mentioned that these slaves are Boyars, or that the Aga Kagans intend to enslave the Boyans. "Planet-grabbers" and the second quote used by A is very vague, it doesn't mention enslavement or Boyars, it's just pure extrapolation.

I feel like I'm missing some context or some broader perspective.
A) The quotes you provide are vague. "nasty habits" is the only new description of the nature of conflict between the Aga Kagans and Boyars. By your own admission, that addition isn't even by Retief, so I can't count it.
B) I like how you emphasize Imperialism and planet-grabbers being terms alluding more to war than slavery. If possible, I would still like some additional evidence focusing on violent conflict rather than enslavement. Using the same quote again isn't super persuasive.

I included the quote by the Boyar to highlight why, in the context of the conversation Retief is having, the Corps are interested in intervening. I'm not sure what textual evidence could be provided to marshal support for either side here other than pointing out the fact that the AK are slavers (q1) and that this is under discussion and on the mind of Retief (q1&2) to justify Corps intervention in the conflict between the AK and Boyars.

The Corps have an investment in preventing war. The first quote I provided should be enough on its own, it directly answers the question. The first quote is from Retief, so according to Retief, if he doesn't bring back evidence of Corps backing, or Corps involvement, the Boyars and the AK will go to war. 

The evidence and analysis from A is still vague and mostly conjecture. Even if the AK are slavers, there's no evidence that Retief is worried about the Boyars being enslaved by the AK. Weigh how directly the first quote I provided answers the question vs. how much extrapolation A is doing.
Leaning B. As evidence for slavery started strong, but fell off as time went on. B seems more compelling.
More ev for B, ev from A is vague and disconnected.

answers.reason for outcome: B had better evidence in the later speeches.

answers.other: Slight note of frustration to whoever judged this, bruh how was the first quote not an instant voter, it answers the question so quickly and directly, and I don't think the issue was that you couldn't tell it was from Retief lol.
answers.reason for outcome: I had pretty conclusive evidence and A didn't have much to work with.
I had to lie and lying is hard.
